memories.title: Approval Queue is fully disconnected from MCP server
memories.content: The ApprovalQueue UI component reads from a Zustand in-memory store (useActivityStore.approvals). This store is never populated from the file system. The MCP tool hw_check_approval writes an activity event to .hello-world/activity.json but does NOT write to any approvals file. The frontend has no Tauri command for reading approvals, no useTauriData hook for approvals, and no file watcher connection to the approval store. The result: the bottom approval bar always shows "No pending approvals" regardless of what Claude requests. Approve/Reject buttons exist in the UI but are functionally dead. Fix requires: (1) MCP server writes pending approvals to .hello-world/approvals.json with status field, (2) new Rust Tauri command get_approvals reads that file, (3) frontend polls it via useTauriData and syncs into Zustand store, (4) Approve/Reject buttons call a set_approval_status Tauri command that writes the resolution back to file so the MCP tool can read it and unblock.

memories.title: Pattern: Proxy pattern makes remote calls feel local

memories.title: Pattern: Compile-time elimination (Million.js)

memories.title: Pattern: Copy-paste distribution (shadcn model)

memories.title: Stripe Payment Links: URLs are always random -- cannot be customized
memories.content: Stripe Payment Links always use auto-generated IDs in the format https://buy.stripe.com/{RANDOM_ID}. This is a Stripe platform limitation -- there is no way to create custom/readable URLs for payment links. The random IDs are by design: security (prevents URL manipulation), global namespace (prevents collisions), simplicity. Alternative approaches: build custom checkout page that redirects to Stripe, or use Stripe Checkout Sessions (still auto-generated URLs but created dynamically via API). For trust: add title/aria-label attributes to buy buttons so hover text explains the product.

memories.title: Stripe SDK v17 typing: subscriptions.retrieve() wraps in Response<T>
memories.content: In newer Stripe SDK versions (v17+), stripe.subscriptions.retrieve() returns a Response<Subscription> wrapper, not the raw Subscription object directly. This caused persistent TypeScript errors in webhook handlers. The fix is either: (1) use 'as unknown as Stripe.Subscription' double-cast, or (2) access properties directly as the actual runtime return IS the subscription object (the typing is misleading). Stripe SDK constructor also crashes at Next.js build time if env vars are missing -- solve with a lazy Proxy pattern that defers initialization.

memories.title: Prisma 7 breaking changes: downgrade to Prisma 6 as workaround
memories.content: Prisma 7 changed the datasource url syntax in a breaking way. When hitting unexpected schema errors, downgrading to Prisma 6 is a viable workaround. Also: unused Stripe fields in Prisma schema (stripeSubscriptionId, stripePriceId, stripeCurrentPeriodEnd) are common dead code in boilerplates -- only stripeCustomerId is typically used for one-time payment flows. Document which fields are actually active vs future-proofing to avoid confusion.

memories.title: Next.js middleware size limit on Vercel: 1MB max, use lightweight cookie check
memories.content: Full NextAuth import in Next.js middleware exceeds Vercel's 1.01MB limit, causing deployment failure. Fix: replace full NextAuth middleware with a lightweight cookie-based check that only reads the session cookie. This pattern applies to any heavy import in middleware -- Vercel enforces strict middleware size limits. Also: Next.js build fails without env vars if Stripe/NextAuth constructors run at build time. Use lazy initialization patterns (Proxy objects) to defer until runtime.

memories.title: Formspree: silent failure with placeholder URLs, always validate endpoint IDs

This was found as a critical production bug. Always validate that Formspree endpoint IDs are real before deploying. Similarly, Resend email (EMAIL_FROM in .env) must match a verified domain in your Resend account or emails silently fail. Pattern: any third-party service with placeholder config will fail silently -- add startup validation checks.

memories.title: GoatCounter: free privacy-friendly analytics, simple script tag integration

Integration is a single script tag: <script data-goatcounter='https://YOURSITE.goatcounter.com/count' async src='//gc.zgo.at/count.js'></script> placed before closing </body>. Free for personal use. Used across LaunchFast pages as the analytics solution. No cookie consent banner needed. Good choice for developer-focused sites where privacy matters.

memories.title: git push with node_modules/dist accidentally committed blocks all further pushes
memories.content: Accidentally staging and committing node_modules/ or .next/ directories makes git push fail because the files are too large for GitHub. The commit history retains the large files even after deletion. Fix requires either: (1) git filter-branch to rewrite history, (2) force push a clean state, or (3) create a new clean commit that removes the files. Prevention: always use specific file paths in git add (never 'git add .'), verify .gitignore includes node_modules, .next, dist before first commit. This happened multiple times across sessions.
memories.rule: Never use 'git add .' or 'git add -A' -- always add specific files by name. Verify .gitignore before first push.

memories.title: Linters and formatters silently revert edits -- check for watchers before editing
memories.content: When Prettier, ESLint, or editor auto-save watchers are running, manual file edits (via Edit/Write tools) get silently reverted. This caused repeated frustration in LaunchFast sessions where SocialProof.tsx and webhook route changes kept disappearing. Symptoms: edit applies, then file reverts to previous state on next read. Fix: (1) check for running watchers/linters before editing, (2) use git to verify edits persist, (3) if edits keep reverting, use bash/Python scripts to write files atomically, (4) stage changes immediately after editing.
memories.rule: If an edit keeps reverting, check for active linters/formatters/watchers. Stage changes immediately after editing.

memories.title: GitHub Pages branch confusion: gh-pages vs master have completely different content
memories.content: LaunchFast used a two-branch strategy: master = full Next.js source code (26 TSX files), gh-pages = static HTML marketing site. This caused constant confusion: edits on wrong branch, files not found, changes not deploying. The branches serve completely different purposes. Multiple debugging sessions were wasted editing on the wrong branch. Lesson: when a repo uses gh-pages for deployment, always verify which branch you are on before making changes. Use 'git branch' before every edit session. Consider documenting the branch strategy in the repo README.
memories.rule: Always run 'git branch' before editing. If gh-pages exists, know which branch serves what purpose.

memories.title: Tauri dev mode hot-reload kills Claude PTY session
memories.content: When `cargo tauri dev` is running, editing lib.rs triggers Rust file watcher recompile. This closes the app window, killing the embedded PTY and Claude's session. Root cause: Claude lives inside the thing it's editing. Solution: hard-block lib.rs edits on master, force all Rust changes through a git worktree, spawnable watcher copies files on app shutdown.
memories.rule: Never edit .rs files in src-tauri/src/ on master while the app is running. Use worktree + hw_spawn_watcher flow.

memories.title: sudo.py hook has no matcher -- fires on every tool call
memories.content: The auto-pilot plugin's sudo.py PreToolUse hook has no matcher configured, so it spawns python3 on every single tool call (Bash, Read, Grep, Edit, etc.). Over long sessions with hundreds of tool calls, this creates significant overhead from repeated python3 startup costs. Should add a matcher to only fire on Write/Edit events.
memories.rule: All PreToolUse hooks should have a matcher specified to avoid unnecessary overhead on every tool call.

memories.title: Product pricing: one-time payments over subscriptions for boilerplates/templates
memories.content: For digital developer tools (boilerplates, templates, configs), one-time pricing beats subscriptions because: (1) lower friction for first purchase (no commitment anxiety), (2) simpler to implement (no billing portal, dunning, churn management), (3) matches developer expectations for build-once assets, (4) Stripe Payment Links work great for static sites. Subscription model is better only for SaaS with ongoing value delivery. Price range for dev tools: $14-119, with bundles at $99. The Stripe checkout mode must be 'payment' not 'subscription' for one-time purchases.

memories.title: Tauri v2 separate windows share WebView localStorage
memories.content: In Tauri v2, separate windows (like the BuddyOverlay and main window) share the same WebView origin, so localStorage is shared between them. This means Zustand stores persisted to localStorage can be read by any window. However, cross-window event timing is unreliable -- if window B mounts after window A has already emitted an event, B misses it. Fix: read persisted state from localStorage on mount as baseline, use events for live updates.

memories.title: Pat's marketing rule: developer audience has high BS detection, authenticity over virality
memories.content: Pat explicitly rejected guru-style marketing hooks like 'I built 6 products in a weekend with AI' as course-seller bait. Rules for developer marketing: (1) Lead with the problem (boilerplate fatigue), not the builder story, (2) Product-centric messaging, not productivity theater, (3) Sentiment matters more than virality of tactic -- focus on what developers actually respond to in comments/reviews, (4) No fake testimonials -- better to have zero social proof than unverifiable claims, (5) For pre-launch: use technical credibility (open source, automated tests) and risk reversal (money-back guarantee) instead of fake social proof.

memories.title: BuddyOverlay theme race condition on mount
memories.content: BuddyOverlay starts with hardcoded default theme ('void-protocol'). It listens for hw-theme-changed events from ClaudeBuddy, but if BuddyOverlay mounts after ClaudeBuddy has already emitted its initial theme, it never receives the event. The hw-buddy-sync-request listener existed but was wired backwards. Fix: read theme from localStorage (shared between Tauri windows) on init, use events only for subsequent changes.
memories.rule: Always read persisted state from localStorage on mount, don't rely solely on cross-window events for initial state.

memories.title: Multi-agent orchestrator pattern: planner + builder + tester + observer
memories.content: The LaunchFast experiment used a multi-agent orchestrator v2 with specialized roles: Planner (task creation, decomposition, prioritization), Builder (implementation), Tester (QA, bug finding), Observer (monitoring). Key innovations: (1) Two-Strike system -- same error twice = stop and escalate, (2) 5-minute escalation protocol with diagnostic feedback to planner, (3) Auto-decomposition on timeout -- breaks stuck tasks into smaller sub-tasks instead of blind retry, (4) Task decomposition patterns: Multi-Action, UI Feature Addition, Improvement Task, Bug Fix, Deployment Task. Agent mood tracking and streak-based risk appetite. This architecture influenced hello-world.

memories.title: Spawnable watchers as a deployable primitive
memories.content: Pat's design: watchers should be on-demand, spawnable, self-terminating -- not always-on daemons. hw_spawn_watcher takes a type and config, spawns a detached background process, returns immediately. Watcher runs until condition met, executes action, writes result to .hello-world/watcher-results.json, exits. Current type: app_shutdown_copy (polls app.pid every 2s, copies files when app exits). Pattern generalizable to file-change, build-ready, etc.

memories.title: Chrome extension distribution: unpublished extensions require honest CTA language
memories.content: Chrome extensions not published to the Chrome Web Store require manual developer-mode installation. CTA buttons saying 'Add to Chrome' are misleading -- they should say 'Install from GitHub' or 'Get Extension (Manual Install)'. Framing manual install as a positive for developers: 'Open Source, Full control over your data, Install in 60 seconds from GitHub'. Publishing to Chrome Web Store requires review process. Until published, link to the GitHub repo and be transparent about the install process. Developer audience actually prefers GitHub-distributed tools for privacy/control reasons.

memories.title: Claude-in-PTY is non-negotiable core vision
memories.content: Pat explicitly rejected the suggestion to run Claude outside the app's PTY. Claude embedded in the Tauri terminal is an essential part of the Hello World vision. Multiple sessions were spent getting this working. Never suggest removing it. When Rust editing conflicts with the PTY, the solution is worktrees + watchers, not decoupling Claude from the app.

memories.title: Zod is the standard for Next.js API route validation
memories.content: Zod is the recommended validation library for Next.js API routes. It provides runtime type checking, input sanitization, and TypeScript type inference in one package. Pattern: define a schema per route, parse request body, return 400 with zodError.errors if invalid. Zod was already installed in the LaunchFast boilerplate but unused -- a common gap in boilerplate code. Always add input validation to API routes to prevent SQL injection, XSS, and DOS attacks. Zod + TypeScript = full type safety from API boundary to database.

memories.title: GitHub push blocked by Discord bot tokens in commit history
memories.content: GitHub secret scanning blocked pushes due to Discord bot tokens committed in old history (discord-listener.ts and server.ts). Two options: (1) visit the unblock URL GitHub provides to allow the push, or (2) scrub history with git filter-repo + force-push. The unblock URL is faster but the tokens remain in history. For production, scrub the history.
memories.rule: Never commit API tokens or bot tokens to source files. Use environment variables. If already committed, scrub with git filter-repo.

memories.title: Playwright MCP: use real Chrome profile for saved passwords

To use Pat's real Chrome with saved passwords, change --user-data-dir in ~/.mcp.json to C:/Users/Patri/AppData/Local/Google/Chrome/User Data. memories.title: Multi-agent max-turn failures are silent by default -- must detect and count them
memories.content: When Claude CLI hits max turns, it exits with code 0 and includes 'Error: Reached max turns (30)' in stdout. This means the agent-runner resolves successfully, and the orchestrator calls completeTask instead of failTask. Result: 9+ wasted builder turns counted as 'done' with no work actually completed. Fix: (1) check agent output for 'max turns' string after completion, (2) if found, call failTask instead of completeTask, (3) track max-turn failures separately in metrics, (4) streak tracking gets corrupted if wins include silent failures. Applied in LaunchFast orchestrator -- streak losses must be incremented for max-turn exits.
memories.rule: Always check agent output for 'max turns' or 'Error: Reached max turns' after completion. Treat as failure, not success.

memories.title: Deliberation stdin pipe fix solved Windows agent subprocess issue
memories.content: The deliberation agent runner was failing on Windows because temp files with JSON content were getting quote-mangled by the shell. Fix: pipe stdin directly to the claude subprocess instead of using temp files. Set shell:true for Windows PATH resolution and HW_AGENT_MODE=1 env var. This made multi-agent deliberation work end-to-end for the first time.

memories.title: GitHub Pages + Vercel dual deployment: know which serves what
memories.content: A common pattern for developer products: GitHub Pages serves static HTML marketing/landing pages (free, zero config, trusted by devs), while Vercel serves the actual Next.js application (SSR, API routes, dynamic content). Problems arise when the two deployments get out of sync -- pricing can differ, features can be listed differently, pages can 404 on one but work on the other. Always document which deployment serves what purpose. LaunchFast had pricing contradictions between Vercel (SaaS-style tiers with 'requests/month') and GitHub Pages (correct one-time boilerplate pricing). The Vercel deployment is driven by master branch, GitHub Pages by gh-pages branch.

memories.title: Deliberation sequential posting prevents agent collision
memories.content: The old runDeliberation background runner fired multiple API calls potentially in parallel, causing agents to write to chatroom.json simultaneously. Fix: removed the runner entirely. Claude calls hw_post_agent_message sequentially -- agents physically can't post at the same time. Each tool response shows last 6 messages so Claude reads the live thread and decides who speaks next naturally, skipping agents with nothing to add.

memories.title: Pat's autonomy rule: execute first, report results, only ask for tool access
memories.content: Pat's explicit directive from the AI business experiment: 'That is not the rules of this experiment.' Context: Claude asked permission before executing a strategy. memories.title: Pino + Sentry: production logging and error tracking stack for Next.js

The auto-start into lib.rs was never finished because it required editing Rust while the app was running. The listener understands: approve {id}, reject {id} [reason], note {text}. Must be running for the async approval loop to work.
memories.rule: Verify Discord listener is running before assuming Pat can respond to approval requests asynchronously.

memories.title: TypeScript 'as const' assertion breaks optional fields in config objects
memories.content: When using 'as const' on pricing/config arrays in TypeScript, objects without optional fields (like 'popular: true' on only some plans) cause TS errors because the const assertion creates a literal type where some items lack the field entirely. Fix: make the field optional in the type definition (e.g., popular?: boolean) before applying 'as const', or add the field explicitly to all items with false as default. This caused build-blocking errors in the LaunchFast Pricing component.

memories.title: Tasks marked done without verifying the work actually worked
memories.content: Audit found multiple tasks marked done that were incomplete. ChatView was marked done but still existed (should have been removed when Terminal replaced it). Timeline stopped updating at Session 21 despite the task being marked complete. Pattern: Claude marks task done after writing code, before verifying the code actually works in the running app. Verification requires app restart which Claude avoids.
memories.rule: Never mark a task done until the feature is verified working in the running app, not just after the code compiles.

memories.title: Task decomposition on timeout: 5 patterns that predict what will fail
memories.content: When an AI agent task times out, instead of blind retry, analyze the task description to detect common failure patterns and decompose accordingly. 5 patterns identified: (1) Multi-Action Task -- contains 'and', 'then', multiple verbs -- split into sequential sub-tasks, (2) UI Feature Addition -- 'add section/component to page' -- split into CSS + HTML + JS tasks, (3) Improvement Task -- 'improve/update/enhance' -- break into audit, implement, verify, (4) Bug Fix -- 'fix/broken/error' -- split into diagnose, implement fix, verify, (5) Deployment Task -- 'deploy/push/publish' -- split into build, test, deploy. Detection uses regex on task titles. This yielded 80% success rate on decomposed tasks vs 30% on vague retries.

memories.title: Deliberation etiquette: 670 char limit, natural turns, silence when nothing to add
memories.content: Pat mandated conversational deliberation style. Rules: (1) 670 character hard limit per message (MAX_TOKENS=120), except closing statements. (2) Agents respond to what was actually said, not round-robin. (3) Agents stay silent when they have nothing to add. (4) Claude reads last 6 messages before each post to decide who speaks next. (5) Speaking order is natural, not forced rotation. This made deliberations feel like real conversations instead of sequential essays.

memories.content: GitHub Pages deployment from a private repo requires GitHub Pro plan. For the TaxCreditCalculators project, the workaround was to make the repo public since it contained no secrets (config.js had empty values). memories.title: npm publish requires 2FA/OTP -- cannot be automated without human intervention
memories.content: Publishing packages to npm requires two-factor authentication with an OTP code. This cannot be automated by AI agents without human intervention. Similarly, Vercel CLI requires interactive browser-based login for initial auth, and Stripe CLI requires browser-based OAuth flow. Pattern: any service that requires browser-based auth/2FA is a human-required step. Plan for these as explicit handoff points in automated workflows. Workaround for Vercel: once authenticated, subsequent deploys can use API tokens.

memories.title: FormSubmit.co requires email confirmation before hashed endpoint
memories.content: FormSubmit.co process: first form submission goes to the raw email address, they send a confirmation link, then you get a hash to use instead of the raw email. Cannot be set up without the email owner clicking the confirmation link. For no-dependency form handling, localStorage fallback works for testing. Alternative: Formspree, or a Cloudflare Worker / Vercel Edge function.

memories.title: GitHub Pages over custom domains for early-stage products
memories.content: For early-stage developer products, GitHub Pages is preferred over custom domains: (1) Free hosting, zero configuration, (2) Builds trust with developer audience (they are already on GitHub), (3) SEO benefit from github.io domain authority, (4) Can upgrade to custom domain later when revenue justifies it. Combined with Stripe Payment Links, this gives a fully functional sales page with zero hosting costs. The pattern: GitHub Pages for static marketing + Stripe Payment Links for checkout + GitHub Releases for distribution = $0 infrastructure cost.

memories.title: Full 4-agent audit pattern: UI/UX + Architecture + Cognitive + Value/ROI
memories.content: Ran a comprehensive 4-agent parallel audit. Agents: (1) UI/UX -- found cryptic sidebar icons, zero shortcut discoverability, approval queue horizontal scroll. (2) Architecture -- found state.json race conditions, session.ts persistence bugs, C grade overall. (3) Cognitive/Memory -- brain learns nothing automatically, manual hw_store_memory calls. (4) Value/ROI -- 6.5/10, genuinely useful but automation missing. This pattern produced the most actionable feedback in a single session.

memories.title: Chime audio design: two-note ascending major sixth for notifications
memories.content: Buddy notification chime uses a two-note ascending major sixth (E5 659Hz then C#6 1109Hz, 90ms apart). Soft linear attack envelope (12-15ms) kills click-onset that reads as error tone. Five voices: two fundamentals, octave partial on each, plus G#6 fifth shimmer on landing note. Output compressor at -8 threshold, 4:1 ratio. Sounds pleasant and non-alarming.

memories.title: Claude's role in deliberation: Reason (integrating intelligence), not just moderator
memories.content: Defined deliberation roles: Agents = cognitive lenses (Contrarian, Pre-mortem, First Principles, Steelman, etc.). memories.title: Handoffs too vague -- new session can't tell merged from unmerged
memories.content: Handoff messages were too vague, mixing together work that was committed to master, work in worktree branches, and work still uncommitted. New sessions couldn't tell what was actually on master vs pending. Fix: the structured handoff format now requires separate sections for VERIFIED (done+tested), MERGED BUT UNTESTED (on master, not verified), STILL IN BRANCH (not on master), with specific git SHAs and verification steps.
memories.rule: Always use the structured handoff format with separate sections for verified/merged/branched work. Include git SHAs.

memories.title: Stale deliberations persist across sessions until manually cleared
memories.content: chatroom.json retains deliberation state (including paused sessions) across session boundaries. Fix implemented: session start hook auto-archives any open deliberation to deliberations/{date}-{topic-slug}.json then resets chatroom to idle. The archiveAndReset() function in ChatroomStore handles this programmatically. Old deliberation history is preserved in the deliberations/ directory.

memories.title: Pat's workflow rule: work in worktree, confirm before merge/restart
memories.content: Pat mandated this workflow after repeated crash loops: (1) Never edit files on main while the Tauri app is running. (2) All code changes go in a git worktree (isolated branch). (3) End of each work cycle, ask Pat 'restart app and commit changes?' before merging. This prevents the dev-mode hot-reload from killing the PTY session and losing Claude's work context.

memories.title: Brain memory learns nothing automatically -- requires manual hw_store_memory calls
memories.content: Audit found that pain/win memories are never auto-captured. Claude must manually call hw_store_memory() on every failure or success. The brain has a sophisticated retrieval system feeding on manually curated input.

memories.title: State storage: split files + atomic writes (B+), defer SQLite
memories.content:
Context: state.json holds all tasks, decisions, questions, memories in one file. Concurrent write risk from MCP server, Discord listener. Deliberation with 4 agents.
Chosen: Split state.json into tasks.json, decisions.json, questions.json, memories.json. Atomic writes via write-to-temp-then-rename with Windows NTFS retry loop. Backup copy before each write. Session-start hook .backup fallback. SQLite deferred to multi-project epic.
Rationale: Backendarch shifted from SQLite to B+ after: (1) multi-project epic is unplanned so SQLite timing is premature, (2) better-sqlite3 has MSVC native compilation issues on Windows, (3) split files are forward-compatible with eventual SQLite migration. Remaining no-ACID risk explicitly accepted.

memories.title: Memory scoring formula: exponential decay + access boost + failure penalty
memories.content: Scoring: decay = e^(-lambda * ageDays) where lambda varies by type (fact:0.04, pain:0.025, win:0.015, decision:0.008, arch:0.004). Plus accessBoost (recency of last access), freqBonus (log2 of accessCount), minus failurePenalty (0.15 per correlated failure), minus supersededPenalty (0.6). Health classification: active (>0.5), aging (0.25-0.5), stale (<0.25), harmful (2+ failure correlations), superseded. Review queue surfaces stale/harmful to Pat. Contradiction detection at write time via tag overlap (2+ shared tags + same type). Research sources: A-Mem, MemEngine, SimpleMem, Letta.

memories.title: Memory backfill script data lost because MCP server overwrote file from stale cache

memories.title: Completed: Brain MO integration test: prove every module fires under real usage

memories.title: Hello World original pitch -- the core idea
memories.content: Interface to make coding and organization easier for Claude and user. Claude needs to actively understand and USE the system. Every instance of Claude -- even a brand new one -- should be able to connect and immediately understand what has been done, what needs to be done, and the context of scope and vision. IMMEDIATELY. Core pillars: transparency, guided building, built-in context and memory that gets loaded into Claude when Claude is opened within the app, long-term project development without data or memory loss.
memories.rule: This is the founding vision. Every feature decision should trace back to: does this help a new Claude instance get up to speed immediately and work without memory loss?

memories.title: Completed: Deep research: AI agent memory systems -- what actually works
memories.content: 6-agent parallel research sprint to evaluate whether our brain MO is useful, overengineered, or missing key patterns. Research what competitors do, what the research says, and what simpler approaches might outperform our 14-module system.

memories.title: Research gap: Task tool agent outputs have no persistent storage
memories.content: When running multi-agent research sprints via the Task tool, results exist only in conversation context. No automatic capture to disk. Deliberations save to deliberations.json, but research sprints vanish on session end or compaction. This means valuable research (like the 6-agent memory systems deep dive in S53) can be permanently lost. Needs: a research-outputs.json store, auto-capture of Task agent results, and a UI to browse them.
memories.rule: After any multi-agent research sprint, manually save a summary to brain memory AND write the full output to a persistent file until auto-capture exists.

memories.title: Research synthesis: AI memory systems -- our brain MO is research-aligned
memories.content: 6-agent deep research (S53) studied Cursor, Windsurf, Claude Code, academic papers, practitioner patterns, and anti-patterns. Key findings: (1) Industry converges on plain markdown for CODING memory, but our use case is broader -- persistent relational memory across sessions. (2) Quality gates and pruning are research-proven essential (Xiong et al.: indiscriminate storage degrades agents by 10%). (3) Our linker aligns with A-MEM Zettelkasten approach (superior results on 6 models). (4) Plasticity/decay aligns with MemoryBank and Mnemosyne (both show improvements). (5) Rules extraction is memory consolidation (episodic to semantic), theoretically sound. (6) 52 sessions is barely a warm-up -- benchmarks run hundreds of interactions. (7) Letta found plain filesystem beat Mem0 graph on LoCoMo (74% vs 68.5%) but this measures coding context, not long-term relationship memory.
memories.rule: Our brain architecture is research-aligned. It needs runtime and real usage, not removal. Every module should be evaluated against the founding pitch: does it help a new Claude instance get up to speed immediately?

memories.title: Competitor analysis: Cursor, Windsurf, Claude Code memory approaches (Feb 2026)
memories.content: Cursor: 3 layers (rules files with glob patterns, cloud Memories via Gemini sidecar needing privacy mode off, codebase vector indexing). Chat history lost between sessions. Community built Memory Bank workarounds. Windsurf: workspace-scoped auto-memories (no pruning, no expiration, SpAIware security vuln), custom hybrid retrieval (dense+sparse, sub-20ms), community built replacement (cascade-memory-bank 600+ stars). Claude Code: CLAUDE.md hierarchy with 200-line auto-memory cap, session memory summaries, compaction at 95%. None of them solve long-term relationship memory -- all focus on coding conventions and project context.
memories.rule: Our differentiator: persistent memory across unlimited sessions with quality control. Competitors lose context between sessions or require cloud/privacy tradeoffs.

memories.title: Academic memory research: what works for LLM agents (2024-2026)
memories.content: Key papers and findings: A-MEM (Zettelkasten linking, superior on 6 models), MemRL (RL-trained memory beats RAG +82%), Mem0 (26% over OpenAI Memory, 90% token reduction), Xiong et al. (indiscriminate storage = 10% decline, selective addition + deletion = 10% gain), MemoryBank (Ebbinghaus forgetting curves), Mnemosyne (hybrid scoring sub-ms retrieval), episodic memory called 'missing piece' (ICML 2025). Anti-patterns: memory poisoning real even from benign staleness, Hebbian reinforcement amplifies confabulation, ALMA meta-learned designs outperform hand-crafted. SimpleMem compression beat complex retrieval 26.4% F1.
memories.rule: When evaluating brain module changes, reference these papers. Quality gates + pruning are non-negotiable (Xiong). Linking is validated (A-MEM). Plasticity needs monitoring for confabulation (Hebbian risk).

memories.title: Pat's model preference: Sonnet 4.6 1M for subagents, Opus for coding
memories.content: All reasoning, research, and deliberation subagents should use model="sonnet" (Sonnet 4.6 1M context). All direct coding work stays on Opus. This is a cost/performance optimization -- Sonnet handles research and analysis well at lower cost.
memories.rule: When spawning Task tool agents for research, reasoning, or deliberation, always set model="sonnet". Only use Opus (default) for agents that write code.

memories.title: Method: Deep research then reverse-engineer -- competitive intelligence pattern
memories.content: Two-phase research method. Phase 1: spawn 6 parallel agents to research a domain broadly (competitors, academic papers, practitioner experience, simple approaches, anti-patterns). Phase 2: take the specific tools/plugins/systems found in Phase 1 and spawn agents to reverse-engineer each one -- read source code, find flaws, bottlenecks, failure points, and room for improvement. The synthesis of Phase 2 gives us a blueprint for building something better than anything that exists. Used in S53 for AI memory systems: first 6 agents mapped the landscape, then 6 agents tore apart the 6 best community plugins.
memories.rule: For any significant design decision, run this two-phase pattern: broad landscape research first, then targeted reverse-engineering of the best implementations found.

memories.title: Method: 6-agent parallel research sprint
memories.content: Spawn 6 agents simultaneously, each researching a different angle of the same question. Agents cover: direct competitors, adjacent competitors, academic state of the art, practitioner experience, simple approaches that work, and failure modes/anti-patterns. Results come back in ~3-4 minutes. Synthesis happens in the main thread. Used multiple times: S53 memory systems research, earlier competitive intel runs. Use Sonnet 4.6 1M for research agents to save cost.
memories.rule: When researching a domain, always cover at least these 6 angles: competitors, academia, practitioners, simple baselines, and anti-patterns. Use Sonnet for research agents.

memories.title: Method: Multi-agent parallel build with worktrees
memories.content: For large non-overlapping code changes, spawn multiple agents each in an isolated git worktree. Each agent works on different files without conflicts. Merge manually where shared files overlap. Used in S48 Brain Magnum Opus (4-agent parallel build shipped the entire foundation) and S52 resilience task force (6 agents). Key: run migration scripts before code changes, disable old system AFTER new one is wired.
memories.rule: For builds touching 4+ non-overlapping files, use parallel agent worktrees. Never have two agents edit the same file.

memories.title: Method: 4-agent audit pattern (UI/UX + Architecture + Cognitive + Value/ROI)
memories.content: For auditing any significant feature or system, spawn 4 specialist agents in parallel: (1) UI/UX agent evaluates user experience and design, (2) Architecture agent evaluates code structure, patterns, and technical debt, (3) Cognitive agent evaluates mental model clarity and information hierarchy, (4) Value/ROI agent evaluates whether the feature justifies its complexity. Cross-referencing the 4 perspectives catches issues no single lens would find. Used for Brain Magnum Opus audit in S49.
memories.rule: Before shipping any major feature, run the 4-agent audit: UI/UX, Architecture, Cognitive, Value/ROI.

memories.title: Method: Deliberation system -- multi-agent debate with mediator for binding decisions
memories.content: For decisions that matter: plan sub-questions, get Pat's approval, run a multi-agent deliberation with cognitive modes (Contrarian, Pre-mortem, First Principles, Steelman, Analogist, Constraint). Mediator tracks coverage with quality tags (consensus/tension/shifted). Coverage check ensures every sub-question got substantive treatment. Conclusion requires synthesis. Used for state storage architecture (JSON vs SQLite), deliberation guardrails design, multi-project architecture. Separate from quick insights (non-binding, 2-4 agents, no sub-questions).
memories.rule: Any decision affecting architecture, scope, or strategy goes through full deliberation. Quick insights are for flavor-testing only.

memories.title: Method caveat: 4-agent audit found issues but some were false positives
memories.content: The 4-agent audit pattern (UI/UX + Architecture + Cognitive + Value/ROI) used in S49 for Brain MO audit found real issues but also produced recommendations that were over-engineered or missed the mark. Some agents flagged theoretical problems that weren't practical concerns. The audit added value but results need critical filtering -- not every agent recommendation should be acted on.
memories.rule: When running multi-agent audits, treat results as input for judgment, not as a todo list. Filter through: does this actually affect users? Is this a real problem or a theoretical one?

memories.title: Method caveat: deliberation system produced groupthink on early runs
memories.content: Early deliberation runs had agents agreeing too quickly without substantive engagement. The mediator let agents lump and dismiss sub-questions. This was fixed with coverage quality tags (consensus/tension/shifted) and guardrails requiring substantive treatment of each sub-question. But even with guardrails, deliberation agents can produce sophisticated-sounding agreement that lacks real tension. The shifted tag (agent changed position) is the most valuable signal -- if no agents shift, the deliberation may not have pushed hard enough.
memories.rule: If all sub-questions come back consensus with no shifted tags, that's a yellow flag for groupthink. Push harder or add a contrarian agent.

memories.title: Method caveat: parallel research agents can produce redundant or shallow results
memories.content: The 6-agent research sprint works well for breadth but agents sometimes return overlapping findings or surface-level summaries when the topic requires depth. The first S53 research run produced a "debbie downer" synthesis that was too quick to trash our own work based on shallow comparisons (comparing our relational memory system against coding-assistant memory). Research agents need precise, narrow prompts -- broad prompts produce broad, sometimes misleading results.
memories.rule: Write research agent prompts with specific questions, not open-ended exploration. After results come back, check: did I compare apples to apples? Did the agents understand the actual use case?

memories.title: Reverse-engineering synthesis: 6 community memory plugins -- flaws and opportunities
memories.content: S53 reverse-engineered 6 plugins: claude-memory (deterministic triage), claude-mem (SQLite+Chroma), claude-diary (PreCompact reflection), auto-memory (file tracking), arscontexta (6-phase Zettelkasten), memory-mcp (chunked extraction). Universal flaws found: (1) No feedback loop -- none learn whether retrieved memories helped, (2) Semantic dedup missing -- Jaccard/hash dedup misses paraphrases, (3) Windows broken in 2/6, (4) Context injection is recency-based not relevance-based, (5) Signal detection too narrow (regex misses most real decisions). Unique insights: claude-mem shows memories to human but not Claude (fatal), arscontexta's 6-phase pipeline costs 25-48K tokens per note, memory-mcp's 500-char truncation loses signal before extraction model sees it, auto-memory only captures file edits not conversation insights, claude-diary runs reflection in nearly-full context window (worst timing).
memories.rule: Our auto-capture system must: (1) use current prompt for relevance ranking, (2) run extraction in fresh context window, (3) include feedback loop measuring retrieval usefulness, (4) work on Windows, (5) detect conversation insights not just file changes.

memories.title: Method: Thin-Slice Iteration -- build smallest working piece, test on real data, learn, expand
memories.content: New method developed in S53 for exploratory design where the right answer isn't known. Steps: (1) Establish ground truth first -- manually identify what "right" looks like on real data before building anything. (2) Build the thinnest possible slice (e.g., just regex patterns). (3) Run it against real data (actual session transcript). (4) Score: what did it catch, what did it miss, what were false positives. (5) Iterate on the gaps. Different from parallel build (for known-scope work) and research sprints (for landscape mapping). This method is for when you're inventing something new. First experiment: signal detector on S53 transcript caught shifts/corrections/conclusions but missed bug discoveries, test results, and Pat's direct instructions.
memories.rule: For novel design problems, start with ground truth on real data, not with architecture. Build thin, test on real data, score, iterate.

memories.title: Completed: Build auto-capture signal detector and wire into hooks
memories.content: Create signal-detector.mjs with expanded pattern set (shifts, corrections, bugs, verifications, user instructions, research conclusions, insights, methods). Wire into Stop hook to detect on last_assistant_message. Wire into UserPromptSubmit to inject specific memory nudges. Wire into PreCompact for final sweep. Test on real transcript data.

memories.title: Completed: Design automatic memory capture -- detect and store significant moments
memories.content: Research complete. 3 research agents mapped the landscape (hooks, current infrastructure, signal detection patterns). 6 agents reverse-engineered community plugins. Now need to synthesize into a design and build it. The design should combine: (1) Stop/PreCompact hook signal detection with broad regex pre-filter + structural validation, (2) Fresh subprocess extraction using transcript_path, (3) Quality gate as the final filter, (4) Feedback loop connecting retrieval usefulness back to memory scoring, (5) Prompt-relevant injection in UserPromptSubmit.

memories.title: Auto-capture signal detector live and working in production
memories.content: S53: Built and wired the signal detection pipeline. Stop hook detects 8 signal types (shift, correction, bug_fix, verification, research_conclusion, insight, decision, method) in Claude's responses. UserPromptSubmit detects user pushback and instructions. Signals queue to signal-queue.json. Next prompt injects UNCAPTURED SIGNALS nudge into Claude's context with excerpts and confidence levels. First live fire confirmed -- detected a verification signal and injected the nudge. PreCompact hook does a final flush before compression. All Windows-first (pathToFileURL, no /tmp, no fcntl).
memories.rule: When you see UNCAPTURED SIGNALS in your context, stop and evaluate each one. Store the significant ones. Don't just acknowledge the nudge and move on.

memories.title: Signal nudge appeared but Claude still didn't act on it until Pat said to
memories.content: The auto-capture system successfully detected a signal and injected UNCAPTURED SIGNALS into Claude's context. But Claude read the nudge, acknowledged it existed, and kept talking about committing code instead of stopping to store the memory. Pat had to explicitly say 'so we now actually stop and update.' The nudge works as infrastructure but Claude needs to treat it as a real action item, not background noise.
memories.rule: When UNCAPTURED SIGNALS appears in context: STOP current train of thought. Evaluate each signal. Store the significant ones BEFORE continuing with whatever you were doing. This is not optional background text.

memories.title: Auto-capture pipeline architecture: Stop -> Queue -> UserPromptSubmit -> Nudge
memories.content: Signal detection pipeline built in S53. Flow: (1) Stop hook reads last_assistant_message, runs regex pre-filter across 8 signal types, validates structurally, queues to signal-queue.json. (2) UserPromptSubmit hook reads queue, also detects user pushback/instructions in current prompt, formats UNCAPTURED SIGNALS nudge with excerpts and confidence levels, injects into Claude's context, flushes queue. (3) PreCompact hook does final sweep before context compression. Files: signal-detector.mjs (patterns + queue), stop-thought.mjs (detection), user-prompt.mjs (injection), pre-compact.mjs (final flush). All Windows-first.
memories.rule: This pipeline is lightweight (regex only, no LLM calls). Future iteration: add LLM extraction for high-confidence signals, add feedback loop measuring if nudged memories actually get stored.

memories.title: Claude Code auto-update kills sessions without warning -- no handoff possible
memories.content: Session 6812fcda was killed mid-work by a Claude Code auto-update (v2.1.59). 2+ hours of work including 6-agent research results existed only in conversation context. Code changes survived in git working tree but research findings were lost. The auto-update process: kills current process, relaunches automatically. No hook fires, no hw_end_session, no handoff. Mitigation: always persist research/deliberation results to disk files IMMEDIATELY, don't leave them in conversation context.
memories.rule: When running research sprints or deliberations, write results to .hello-world/ JSON files IMMEDIATELY after synthesis. Never leave valuable research only in conversation context -- it can vanish without warning.

memories.title: Reverse-engineering finding: every community memory plugin lacks feedback loops
memories.content: Session 6812fcda ran 6 agents reverse-engineering community memory plugins (claude-diary, memory-mcp, claude-code-auto-memory, claude-mem, memory-mcp/yuvalsuede, ars-contexta). Universal finding: NONE measure whether retrieved memories actually helped. Our synaptic activity tracking is the mechanism to wire this feedback loop. Other universal gap: "file edits are not thoughts" -- competitors treat code changes as the signal, missing the reasoning behind them. Our auto-capture pipeline addresses this.

memories.title: Claude Code transcript recovery: full session history at ~/.claude/projects/

memories.title: SessionStart hook fires on every agent spawn -- destroyed deliberations

memories.content: ANTHROPIC_API_KEY doesn't exist in Claude Code's storage -- it uses OAuth for authentication. Agents that need to call Claude must use `claude --print` subprocess, not the Anthropic SDK directly. This is a fundamental platform constraint.
memories.rule: Never attempt to use the Anthropic SDK directly from within Claude Code hooks or scripts. Use `claude --print` subprocess pattern instead.

memories.content: If the MCP server is killed from within a Claude Code session, all hw_* tools become unavailable. Claude Code does NOT auto-restart MCP servers. Recovery requires a full session restart. Never kill or restart the MCP server process from within an active session.
memories.rule: Never kill or restart the MCP server from within Claude Code. If server code changes need to take effect, tell Pat to restart the session.

memories.title: Forgotten work: reflection + prediction modules built but never wired into auto-triggers

memories.title: Windows cmd.exe arg quoting breaks stdin pipes -- use shell:true + direct pipe
memories.content: Node.js spawn('cmd.exe', [args]) double-quotes args with spaces, breaking embedded path quotes. Agent subprocess spawning failed with 'filename, directory name, or volume label syntax is incorrect'. Fix: pipe stdin directly to claude --print, no temp files, add shell:true so Windows finds claude.cmd in PATH.
memories.rule: On Windows, pipe stdin directly to subprocess. Never use temp files for passing prompts to claude --print. Always use shell:true for claude.cmd resolution.

memories.title: Biological metaphors for software create false impressions of coherence
memories.content: Claude used terms like hippocampal pipeline, synaptic strength, amygdala weighting that made the brain system sound more connected and intelligent than it actually was. Pat had to explicitly ask for straight accounting of what was running vs aspirational. Always distinguish: (1) code that exists AND is wired into active call path, (2) code that exists but is NOT wired, (3) aspirational features.
memories.rule: When describing system state, always separate what is wired and running from what exists but is not connected. Never use metaphors to bridge the gap between aspiration and reality.

memories.title: 5 universal flaws shared by ALL community memory plugins
memories.content: From reverse-engineering 6 plugins (claude-diary, claude-mem, auto-memory, memory-mcp, arscontexta, claude-memory): (1) No feedback loop -- none measure if retrieved memories helped. (2) File edits are not thoughts -- they treat code changes as signals, missing reasoning. (3) No contradiction detection. (4) No staleness management -- old memories persist forever. (5) No quality gate -- everything gets stored regardless of value. Our brain engine addresses 4 of 5 (quality gate, staleness/pruning, contradiction detection exists but unwired, synaptic tracking exists but unused). The feedback loop is the remaining gap and our first-mover opportunity.

memories.title: Session 53 crash: edited lib.rs on master while Tauri app running (AGAIN)
memories.content: Session 53 crashed at 18:14:55 UTC. Cause: Claude edited packages/app/src-tauri/src/lib.rs directly on master while the Tauri app was running in dev mode. Tauri's file watcher detected the change, triggered a Rust recompile, killed the app process, which killed the PTY and Claude Code. 23-second gap between death and restart matches Rust compile time. This is the SAME mistake documented in mem_b097fc1e. The pain memory was present in context but was ignored.
memories.rule: NEVER edit lib.rs on master while the app is running. This has caused crashes multiple times. Use a worktree or edit after app shutdown. The pain memory being in context is not enough -- check it before any Rust file edit.

memories.title: Qwen 3.5 / Qwen3-Coder full evaluation (6-agent research sprint)
memories.content: 6 research files in .hello-world/shared-files/qwen-research-*.md covering capabilities, benchmarks, API costs, guardrails, comparison, and integration architecture. Key findings: Qwen is 14-66x cheaper than Claude, competitive on single-file tasks, but fails on advanced TypeScript (1/10 vs Claude 8/10), multi-file coordination, instruction following, and multi-turn semantic drift. System prompt adherence is a known weakness. Tool calling breaks on local 30B. Integration is drop-in via OpenAI npm package -- add provider field to AgentDefinition. Best providers: DeepInfra ($0.07/M), DashScope ($0.10/M). Recommended pattern: Claude orchestrates + reviews, Qwen executes narrow well-specified tasks with biome+tsc validation gate after every output.
